questions.question: Which command is equivalent to 'docker create' followed by 'docker start'?
questions.explanation: The 'docker run' command is a high-level command that creates a new container from an image and then starts it.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'docker run' and 'docker exec'?

options.text: run creates a new container; exec works on a running one
exec creates a new container; run works on a running one
run is for images; exec is for volumes

questions.explanation: Use 'docker run' when you want to create a fresh container instance. Use 'docker exec' when you want to run a specific command (like opening a shell) inside a container that is already active.

questions.question: Which flag is used to run a container in the background (detached mode)?
questions.explanation: The -d (detached) flag tells Docker to run the container in the background and print the container ID.

questions.question: What does the '--rm' flag do?

options.text: Removes the image after the container stops
Forces the container to restart if it fails
Automatically removes the container when it exits

questions.explanation: The --rm flag is excellent for one-off tasks as it cleans up the container (and its local disk space) immediately after the process finishes.

questions.question: How does 'docker stop' differ from 'docker kill'?

options.text: kill is graceful, stop is immediate
stop sends SIGTERM; kill sends SIGKILL
stop removes the container; kill does not

questions.explanation: docker stop sends a SIGTERM signal to the process, allowing it to save its state and shut down cleanly. If it doesn't stop within 10 seconds, it sends SIGKILL. docker kill sends SIGKILL immediately.
